justification: The article states that the studies compared "standard behavioural tasks" with other methods when measuring "risk-sensitivity," indicating that these tasks serve as one instrument for assessing the construct.

It notes that the authors compared "personality questionnaires" with behavioural tasks and found the questionnaires more reliable, showing that questionnaires are used to measure the same risk-sensitivity construct.
The text explains that "the frequency measures were assessed using self-report questionnaires," linking the construct (real-life risky-behaviour frequency) to its measurement instrument.
The article says "the mathematical model used to quantify risk propensity parameters" focused on CPT, indicating that CPT-derived parameters are employed as a measure of risk propensity.

Under the ‘problem with the measure’ section, the authors argue that "behavioural tasks provide a genuine estimate of the subject's momentary risk attitude at the time of testing," directly linking behavioural tasks to the construct of momentary risk attitude.
